2:Taa1,{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Recipe","name":"Bondiola al Pan","description":"A slow-roasted pork shoulder sandwich that's one of Buenos Aires' best street foods. The bondiola is roasted for hours until falling-apart tender, then piled into crusty bread with chimichurri and salsa criolla.","image":"https://expatsargentina.com/images/recipes/bondiola.webp","author":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Expats Argentina"},"datePublished":"2025-01-01","prepTime":"PT20M","cookTime":"PT3M","totalTime":"PT23M","recipeYield":"8 servings","recipeCategory":"main","recipeCuisine":"Argentine","keywords":"bondiola recipe, argentine pork sandwich, bondiola al pan, street food buenos aires, slow roast pork shoulder","nutrition":{"@type":"NutritionInformation","calories":"520 calories","proteinContent":"32g","carbohydrateContent":"38g","fatContent":"26g"},"recipeIngredient":["For the bondiola: 1.5 kg (3.3 lbs) boneless pork shoulder (bondiola/coppa)","For the bondiola: 4 cloves garlic, minced","For the bondiola: 2 tbsp smoked paprika","For the bondiola: 1 tbsp ground cumin","For the bondiola: 1 tbsp dried oregano","For the bondiola: 2 tbsp olive oil","For the bondiola: 1 cup beef or chicken broth","For the bondiola: Salt and black pepper","For serving: 8 crusty bread rolls (pan francés)","For serving: Chimichurri sauce","For serving: Salsa criolla (diced onion, tomato, bell pepper in vinegar and oil)"],"recipeInstructions":[{"@type":"HowToStep","position":1,"text":"Score the surface of the pork shoulder in a crosshatch pattern, about 1/2 inch deep."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":2,"text":"Mix garlic, paprika, cumin, oregano, olive oil, salt, and pepper into a paste. Rub thoroughly all over the pork, pressing into the scores."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":3,"text":"Let the pork marinate at room temperature for 30 minutes (or overnight in the fridge for best results)."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":4,"text":"Preheat oven to 325°F (160°C). Place the pork in a roasting pan and pour the broth around it."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":5,"text":"Cover tightly with foil and roast for 2 hours."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":6,"text":"Remove the foil, increase heat to 400°F (200°C), and roast another 45-60 minutes until the exterior is deeply caramelized and the internal temperature reaches 190°F (88°C)."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":7,"text":"Rest the meat for 15 minutes, then shred or slice thickly against the grain."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":8,"text":"Toast the bread rolls lightly on the grill or in the oven."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":9,"text":"Pile shredded bondiola onto the bread, spoon chimichurri over the meat, and top with salsa criolla."}]}0:{"buildId":"XJ7f5RvYDcX4yjbAXmNYG","rsc":["$","$1","c",{"children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"min-h-screen bg-gradient-to-b from-orange-50 to-white","children":[["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"$2"}}],["$","div",null,{"className":"border-b bg-white/80 backdrop-blur-sm sticky top-0 z-40 print:hidden","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-5xl mx-auto px-4 py-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"flex items-center justify-between","children":["$","$L3",null,{"href":"/food/recipes","children":[["$","svg",null,{"xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","width":24,"height":24,"viewBox":"0 0 24 h-4","aria-hidden":"true","children":["$L4","$L5","$undefined"]}],"All Recipes"],"data-slot":"button","data-variant":"ghost","data-size":"sm","className":"inline-flex items-center justify-center whitespace-nowrap text-sm font-medium transition-all disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:opacity-50 [&_svg]:pointer-events-none [&_svg:not([class*='size-'])]:size-4 shrink-0 [&_svg]:shrink-0 outline-none focus-visible:border-ring focus-visible:ring-ring/50 focus-visible:ring-[3px] aria-invalid:ring-destructive/20 dark:aria-invalid:ring-destructive/40 aria-invalid:border-destructive gap-2","ref":null}]}]}]}],"$L6","$L7","$L8"]}],null,"$L9"]}],"loading":null,"isPartial":false}

17:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm bg-gradient-to-br from-amber-50 to-orange-50 border-amber-100 print:bg-none print:border-gray-300","id":"tips","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-2 text-xl","children":[["$","svg",null,{"xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","width":24,"height":24,"viewBox":"0 0 24 24","fill":"none","stroke":"currentColor","strokeWidth":2,"strokeLinecap":"round","strokeLinejoin":"round","className":"lucide lucide-lightbulb w-5 h-5 text-amber-600","aria-hidden":"true","children":[["$","path","1gvzjb",{"d":"M15 14c.2-1 .7-1.7 1.5-2.5 1-.9 1.5-2.2 1.5-3.5A6 6 0 0 0 6 8c0 1 .2 2.2 1.5 3.5.7.7 1.3 1.5 1.5 2.5"}],["$","path","x1upvd",{"d":"M9 18h6"}],["$","path","ceow96",{"d":"M10 22h4"}],"$undefined"]}],"Pro Tips from the Kitchen"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","ul",null,{"className":"space-y-3","children":[["$","li","0",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Low and slow is the key — rushing the cook at high heat will result in tough, dry pork. The long roast at low temperature renders the fat and collagen."}]]}],["$","li","1",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Scoring the meat allows the spice rub to penetrate deeper and creates more crispy surface area."}]]}],["$","li","2",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"The bread matters — it needs to be crusty enough to hold up to the juicy meat without falling apart."}]]}]]}]}]]}]
18:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm print:shadow-none print:border-gray-300","id":"history","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-2 text-xl","children":[["$","svg",null,{"xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","width":24,"height":24,"viewBox":"0 0 24 24","fill":"none","stroke":"currentColor","strokeWidth":2,"strokeLinecap":"round","strokeLinejoin":"round","className":"lucide lucide-history w-5 h-5 text-orange-600","aria-hidden":"true","children":[["$","path","1357e3",{"d":"M3 12a9 9 0 1 0 9-9 9.75 9.75 0 0 0-6.74 2.74L3 8"}],["$","path","1xhq8a",{"d":"M3 3v5h5"}],["$","path","1fdv2h",{"d":"M12 7v5l4 2"}],"$undefined"]}],"The Story Behind the Dish"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700 leading-relaxed","children":"Bondiola (pork shoulder or neck) became a street food star in Buenos Aires in the 2000s, as food truck and market culture grew. Vendors would slow-roast whole bondiolas over charcoal for hours, then carve them to order into crusty rolls. The trend exploded at events like Buenos Aires Market and Masticar food festival. Today, bondiola al pan stands are fixtures at outdoor markets, festivals, and the Costanera Sur waterfront."}]}]]}]
19:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm print:shadow-none print:border-gray-300","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6 pb-3","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold text-lg","children":"Storage & Leftovers"}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-0","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Refrigerate cooked bondiola for up to 4 days. Reheat gently in a 300°F (150°C) oven wrapped in foil with a splash of broth. Shred and assemble sandwiches fresh."}]}]]}]
